citation.article-title: Corynebacterium seminale sp. nov., a new species associated with genital infections in male patients.

p.s: Description of Corynebacterium seminale sp. nov.
Corynebacterium seminale (se.mi.na'le. L. neut. adj. seminale, pertaining to the semen, sperma)
The description is based on the data for the 12 strains included in this study.
The bacteria are gram-positive, pleomorphic, clubbed, nonmotile rods occurring in pairs or V-shaped forms.
They are non-spore forming.
They are catalase positive, oxidase negative, and facultatively anaerobic.
Colonies on 1% (vol/vol) sheep blood agar are white-grey-beige, slightly convex, and from 1 to 2 mm in size after 48 h at 37°C.
They are non-betahemolytic, but the CAMP test is strongly positive with the use of a β-hemolysin-producing S. aureus strain.
Reduction of nitrate occurs variably, and hydrolyses of urea and esculin are variable.
Tyrosine and gelatin are not degraded, but starch, arginine, and hippurate are hydrolyzed.
Acid is produced from D-glucose, ribose, and sucrose but not from D-mannitol, lactose, trehalose, or glycogen.
Fermentation of maltose and xylose occurs variably.
Cells produce pyrazinamidase and β-glucuronidase, but alkaline phosphatase, pyrrolidonylarylamidase, β-galactosidase, α-glucosidase, and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase are not produced.
The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid, arabinose, and galactose.
Mycolic acids with short chain lengths (C26 to C36) are present.
The DNA base composition is 60 mol% G+C (by the capillary electrophoresis procedure). C. seminale strains were isolated from human specimens, mainly from semen cultures.
The type strain is IBS B12915 (CIP 104297).
It was isolated in Strasbourg, France, from the semen of a patient with prostatitis.
This strain has all of the above-described properties for the species.
Acid is produced from maltose and xylose, urea is hydrolyzed, nitrate is not reduced, and esculin is not hydrolyzed.
